articles.headline: Fight on Guns Is Being Taken to State Ballots
articles.snippet: The gun control movement, facing mounting losses in federal elections, is tweaking its name, refining its goals and using the gay-marriage movement as a model.
articles.abstract: The gun control movement, facing mounting losses in federal elections, is tweaking its name, refining its goals and using the gay-marriage movement as a model.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The gun control movement, blocked in Congress and facing mounting losses in federal elections, is tweaking its name, refining its goals and using the same-sex marriage movement as a model to take the fight to voters on the state level.

articles.headline: A Stress Test for Mario Draghi and the European Central Bank
articles.snippet: In doing “whatever it takes” to save the eurozone, the head of the European Central Bank now risks dividing it.
articles.abstract: In doing “whatever it takes” to save the eurozone, the head of the European Central Bank now risks dividing it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mario Draghi indulged the photographers and their rapid-fire shutters for a few moments, making his first appearance for the news media in the European Central Bank’s ostentatious new high-rise headquarters in Frankfurt.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: Easing Into Leisure, One Step at a Time
articles.snippet: A growing number of Americans are downsizing and retiring in multiple steps, continuing to work at least part time and moving more than once.
articles.abstract: A growing number of Americans are downsizing and retiring in multiple steps, continuing to work at least part time and moving more than once.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 54, Jack M. Guttentag decided to downsize. His children had grown, and he and his wife thought they should prepare for the future and move from their townhouse in Philadelphia to something countrified, a few dozen miles west in Valley Forge, Pa.

articles.headline: More Sanctions on North Korea After Sony Case
articles.snippet: The Obama administration doubled down on its allegation that North Korea’s leadership was behind the hacking of Sony Pictures.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration doubled down on its allegation that North Korea’s leadership was behind the hacking of Sony Pictures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration doubled down on Friday on its allegation that North Korea’s leadership was behind the hacking of Sony Pictures, announcing new, if largely symbolic, economic sanctions against 10 senior North Korean officials and the intelligence agency it said was the source of “many of North Korea’s major cyberoperations.”
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Unruly Factions Hurt Taliban’s Bid to Capture Afghan Hearts, and Territory
articles.snippet: Factions of the movement have hardened, while others are involved in kidnappings, robberies and the opium trade — damaging the Taliban’s efforts to win over the Afghan population.
articles.abstract: Factions of the movement have hardened, while others are involved in kidnappings, robberies and the opium trade — damaging the Taliban’s efforts to win over the Afghan population.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A series of kidnappings and robberies struck northern Helmand Province this summer, paralyzing residents and embarrassing the Taliban leaders who controlled the area.

articles.headline: Ferran Adrià Feeds the Hungry Mind
articles.snippet: Ferran Adrià, a groundbreaking Spanish chef whose El Bulli was one of the world’s top restaurants before he closed it, is now on an idiosyncratic quest for knowledge and creativity.
articles.abstract: Ferran Adrià, a groundbreaking Spanish chef whose El Bulli was one of the world’s top restaurants before he closed it, is now on an idiosyncratic quest for knowledge and creativity.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day in November, Ferran Adrià, the Spanish chef who turned foods into foams and pioneered a new era in gastronomic innovation while running one of the world’s most popular restaurants, bounced through a loft space in Barcelona. He peered at pencil-sketched mind maps tacked to plastic foam bulletin boards and examined books jammed on narrow shelves — until he reached the end of a display table featuring a variety of Asian soup spoons. Then he stopped.

articles.headline: Gasoline-Tax Increase Finds Little Support
articles.snippet: Advocates like Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee find it tough to penetrate Washington’s antitax mood, even as gas prices fall and federal transportation funds face huge deficits.
articles.abstract: Advocates like Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee find it tough to penetrate Washington’s antitax mood, even as gas prices fall and federal transportation funds face huge deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: When gasoline topped $4 a gallon, opponents of an increase in the gas tax argued that prices were already too high.

articles.headline: New Zealand Glaciers Ebb and Tour Guides Play Catch-Up
articles.snippet: With winter weather more unpredictable in many parts of the world, companies offering tours through ice and snow find an uneven effect on business.
articles.abstract: With winter weather more unpredictable in many parts of the world, companies offering tours through ice and snow find an uneven effect on business.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOX GLACIER, New Zealand — This town of about 300 residents trades on its namesake: a giant slab of ice and snow a short drive from the main street. Guided glacier hiking began here in 1928 and is a main reason for the area’s popularity as a destination for international travelers.

articles.headline: Euro Falls Lower as Central Bank Hints at Increase in Stimulus Plan
articles.snippet: Statements by Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, led investors to conclude that the bank would soon buy large quantities of eurobonds.
articles.abstract: Statements by Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, led investors to conclude that the bank would soon buy large quantities of eurobonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, may be pushing hard for a weaker euro to spur growth in Europe, but his central bank peers seem to be several steps ahead of him.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: After a Spa Day, Looking Years Younger (O.K., They’re Only 7)
articles.snippet: The spa industry is going way beyond mother-daughter manicures to offer a range of massages, facials and other treatments for young girls (and sometimes boys).
articles.abstract: The spa industry is going way beyond mother-daughter manicures to offer a range of massages, facials and other treatments for young girls (and sometimes boys).
articles.lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — It was a day out at the spa for Paige Ehresman and her closest friends. Manicures. Hairdos. Makeup. And some gossip — about second grade.

articles.headline: Whole Foods’ High Hurdle for Investors
articles.snippet: Whole Foods Market got the S.E.C.’s permission to exclude from its proxy a shareholder proposal on director nominations, and 10 other companies now want to do the same.
articles.abstract: Whole Foods Market got the S.E.C.’s permission to exclude from its proxy a shareholder proposal on director nominations, and 10 other companies now want to do the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shareholders own the companies they invest in, but they have long been largely shut out of any role in naming the people who are supposed to represent them: corporate directors.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Employees With Ties Abroad See Security Bias
articles.snippet: An F.B.I. program aimed at reducing internal threats is said to be penalizing employees hired for their foreign language skills by subjecting them to higher scrutiny.
articles.abstract: An F.B.I. program aimed at reducing internal threats is said to be penalizing employees hired for their foreign language skills by subjecting them to higher scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. is subjecting hundreds of its employees who were born overseas or have relatives or friends there to an aggressive internal surveillance program that started after Sept. 11, 2001, to prevent foreign spies from coercing newly hired linguists but that has been greatly expanded since then.

articles.headline: The Economics (and Nostalgia) of Dead Malls
articles.snippet: High-end shopping malls are thriving across the country, but as midtier retailers like Sears and J. C. Penney flounder, they are also dragging down their malls.
articles.abstract: High-end shopping malls are thriving across the country, but as midtier retailers like Sears and J. C. Penney flounder, they are also dragging down their malls.
articles.lead_paragraph: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — Inside the gleaming mall here on the Sunday before Christmas, just one thing was missing: shoppers.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Turns to the Courts to Aid Agenda
articles.snippet: As Republicans prepare to take full control of Congress on Tuesday, they are counting on judges, not their new majority, to block President Obama’s second-term agenda.
articles.abstract: As Republicans prepare to take full control of Congress on Tuesday, they are counting on judges, not their new majority, to block President Obama’s second-term agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Republicans prepare to take full control of Congress on Tuesday, the party’s leaders are counting on judges, not their newly elected majority on Capitol Hill, to roll back President Obama’s aggressive second-term agenda and block his executive actions on health care, climate change and immigration.

articles.headline: Ukraine Leader Was Defeated Even Before He Was Ousted
articles.snippet: President Viktor F. Yanukovych was not so much overthrown as cast adrift by his own allies, and Western officials were just as surprised by the meltdown as anyone else.
articles.abstract: President Viktor F. Yanukovych was not so much overthrown as cast adrift by his own allies, and Western officials were just as surprised by the meltdown as anyone else.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ashen-faced after a sleepless night of marathon negotiations, Viktor F. Yanukovych hesitated, shaking his pen above the text placed before him in the chandeliered hall. Then, under the unsmiling gaze of European diplomats and his political enemies, the beleaguered Ukrainian president scrawled his signature, sealing a deal that he believed would keep him in power, at least for a few more months.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: At the International CES, the Internet of Things Hits Home
articles.snippet: Household devices that link together through the Internet are likely to energize this year’s International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.
articles.abstract: Household devices that link together through the Internet are likely to energize this year’s International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.
articles.lead_paragraph: By just about any measure, the International Consumer Electronics Show is big. The event, held in Las Vegas, attracts more than 150,000 visitors. It occupies two million square feet, the equivalent of about 35 football fields, of exhibition space. More than 3,500 companies come to show their wares.

articles.headline: Selfies on a Stick, and the Social-Content Challenge for the Media
articles.snippet: The tendency to listen to the holy music of the self is reflected not only in the selfie stick, but also in apps like Snapchat and Instagram, which pose a profound challenge for media companies.
articles.abstract: The tendency to listen to the holy music of the self is reflected not only in the selfie stick, but also in apps like Snapchat and Instagram, which pose a profound challenge for media companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes you don’t need an analyst’s report to get a look at the future of the media industry and the challenges it will bring.

articles.headline: Maoists in China, Given New Life, Attack Dissent
articles.snippet: President Xi Jinping’s traditional leanings, along with Communist Party decrees that have declared open season on dissenters, have emboldened Maoist ideologues.
articles.abstract: President Xi Jinping’s traditional leanings, along with Communist Party decrees that have declared open season on dissenters, have emboldened Maoist ideologues.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — They pounce on bloggers who dare mock their beloved Chairman Mao. They scour the nation’s classrooms and newspapers for strains of Western-inspired liberal heresies. And they have taken down professors, journalists and others deemed disloyal to Communist Party orthodoxy.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Andrew Jacobs

articles.headline: How ‘1989’ Edged Out ‘Frozen’ as the No. 1 Album of 2014, and Vice Versa
articles.snippet: As streaming grows in popularity, competing album sales metrics that yielded two different No. 1 albums illustrate the music industry at a crossroads.
articles.abstract: As streaming grows in popularity, competing album sales metrics that yielded two different No. 1 albums illustrate the music industry at a crossroads.
articles.lead_paragraph: What was the most popular album of 2014? With technology rapidly changing how people listen to music, the answer depends on which numbers you count.

articles.headline: Investigation Discovery Network Makes Crime Pay
articles.snippet: Offering a sensational mix of romance-gone-wrong murder mysteries introduced by celebrity hosts, the network is welcomed into more than 100 million homes in 157 countries and territories.
articles.abstract: Offering a sensational mix of romance-gone-wrong murder mysteries introduced by celebrity hosts, the network is welcomed into more than 100 million homes in 157 countries and territories.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERICHO, N.Y. — In September, Seth Techel received a life sentence in Iowa for murdering his pregnant wife to pursue a romance with a co-worker. In October, a production crew descended on a suburban home in this Long Island town to recreate the drama for an episode of “Scorned: Love Kills,” a popular series on the real-crime network Investigation Discovery.

articles.headline: PlayStation 4 Faces Resurgent Rivals in Xbox One and Wii U
articles.snippet: Sales of Microsoft’s Xbox One and Nintendo’s Wii U are improving, eroding what was once a strong lead for Sony’s PlayStation 4.
articles.abstract: Sales of Microsoft’s Xbox One and Nintendo’s Wii U are improving, eroding what was once a strong lead for Sony’s PlayStation 4.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Not so fast, Sony. Your two biggest rivals in the game console business, Microsoft and Nintendo, are showing signs of life.

articles.headline: Republicans Say They’ll Act Fast to Push Agenda
articles.snippet: Eager to show that they can govern well as they take control of Congress, Republicans aim to quickly advance energy and health care legislation.
articles.abstract: Eager to show that they can govern well as they take control of Congress, Republicans aim to quickly advance energy and health care legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In taking control of Congress on Tuesday, Republicans say they will quickly advance energy and health care legislation that stalled in the Democratic-controlled Senate as they try to make good on claims, and address doubts, that they can govern effectively.

articles.headline: Popular TV Series and Movies Maintain Relevance as Novels
articles.snippet: As television experiences a new golden age, tie-in books, a long-maligned subgenre, have gained respectability.
articles.abstract: As television experiences a new golden age, tie-in books, a long-maligned subgenre, have gained respectability.
articles.lead_paragraph: In “Bratva,” a new crime novel by Christopher Golden, a grizzled motorcycle gang vice president named Jax Teller and his loyal sidekicks Opie and Chibs take on Russian mobsters to rescue Jax’s half sister. Some 200 pages of gun battles, fistfights and mayhem follow.
